awd_titl_txt: POSE: Phase I:  OSE for Consumer and Academic Scale Renewable Energy Adoption
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by Pathways to Enable Open-Source Ecosystems (POSE) which seeks to harness the power of open-source development for the creation of new technology solutions to problems of national and societal importance. The past decade has been characterized by a momentous shift in the energy landscape with over $2.6 trillion invested in the exponential growth of renewable energy (RE). More than 80% of all new electrical generation added in 2020 was from RE sources. However, a great bulk of this addition was for utility (>5MW) and distributed scale generation (>500kW) and not at the consumer level integration.  The main mission of this research project is to scope an open-source ecosystem (OSE) which will increase consumer adoption and support academic teaching and research in the RE space.  The project’s novelties are providing consumers, researchers, and educators with intuitive, easy to operate open-source software and hardware to control, connect, and modify RE systems, along with access to large open data sets to analyze variables that affect various solutions.  The project’s impacts are 1) addressing the legal, security, sustainability, reliability, and training areas needed for a successful OSE around the software, hardware, and data platforms, and 2) enabling pathways for development by growing the user base and creating a community of practice that will demonstrate uses of the products and support ease of mass adoption across multiple sectors in the academic and consumer RE space.  Enhancing these platforms and communities makes the individual consumer and institutional level researcher and educator compete with industry giants in the RE space and serves as a force multiplier in the United States’ quest for energy independence and reduction in greenhouse gasses.  Beyond RE, these platforms have applicability to and can be modified by developers in other relevant fields needing similar solutions such as water ecology and water remediation, small batch manufacturing, and a host of agrisciences.

At the consumer and academia levels, significant barriers to RE implementation remain that need
to be addressed. This project’s team of researchers is focused on three items that have been identified by industry, academia, government, and consumers as critical gaps to broader development and usage of renewables: 1) open-source free Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) interfaces to control and monitor renewable energy assets (software), 2) open-source hardware applications for diagnostic, smart relay, and microinverter purposes to affordably connect, operate, and modify renewables (hardware), and 3) access to large data sets to research and understand all variables associated with renewable integration (data sets).  The project’s scoping activities include training, ecosystem discovery, governance structure, community building, and planning for scale and sustainability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Summary

Over the past two years, Impact Allies focused on building a robust open-source ecosystem (OSE) for the renewable energy sector, emphasizing governance, community growth, and strategic outreach. In the first year, foundational elements such as bylaws, a board of directors, and essential policies were established, supported by training and mentorship. This led to significant engagement with stakeholders, including institutes of higher education and industry partners. The second year saw further expansion, with over 100 users and numerous resources added. Key activities included professional development workshops, national presentations, collaborative efforts with major industry partners, and assessments of how developers and users interacted with and valued the open-source resources and community.

 

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of the Impact Allies project lies in its rapid response to the growing demand for open-source renewable energy (RE) resources, highlighting a critical gap in current academic and industry alignment. Within the first year, the project established a comprehensive framework for an open-source ecosystem (OSE) tailored to the renewable energy sector. This framework included the creation of by-laws, a board of directors, and key operational documents that set a high standard for governance and scalability. The project's swift growth and the extensive interest it garnered from academic institutions and industry partners underscore the urgent need for open-access renewable data sets and standardized equipment. By addressing this demand, Impact Allies provided critical tools that enable educators to incorporate cutting-edge RE technologies into their curricula, bridging a significant gap between academic training and the rapidly evolving industry landscape.

 

Further enhancing its intellectual contribution, the project conducted a broad survey of the renewable energy sector, identifying specific areas where open-source solutions could have the most substantial impact. Through professional development workshops and collaborative outreach, Impact Allies successfully engaged over 100 users across diverse institutions, demonstrating the scalability and adaptability of its resources. The project’s case studies and dissemination efforts at key national conferences validated the effectiveness of the OSE model, which integrates best practices from both academic and industry perspectives. This convergence of interests highlights the value of freely accessible RE resources, enabling academic programs to keep pace with industry advancements and better prepare the future workforce for emerging challenges in renewable energy.

 

Broader Impacts 

The broader impact of Impact Allies' open-source ecosystem (OSE) project is evident not only in the renewable energy sector but also as a replicable model for other critical fields such as food security, water management, and environmental sustainability. By demonstrating the tangible value of open-source data sets and equipment in bridging the gap between academia and industry, the project highlighted the potential for similar innovations across diverse sectors facing rapid technological change. The initiative's success was particularly impactful in academic settings, especially at community colleges and K-12 institutions, where limited budgets often hinder access to up-to-date software and hardware. Through its provision of free, high-quality open-source tools, Impact Allies empowered these educational institutions to integrate cutting-edge renewable technologies into their programs, enhancing learning outcomes and better preparing students for industry demands. This approach shows a promising pathway for broader adoption, creating accessible educational resources that can adapt to the evolving needs of various disciplines.


 

 


Last Modified: 12/18/2024
Modified by: Benjamin Reid
